ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The sense of spiritual lineage within the American Experimental Tradition and a thorough understanding of its literary predecessors in the 19th century.
Ability to rethink the notion of an experimental canon through the unfamiliar lens of personal religion; a valuable exercise in critical thinking using a mode not discussed often enough

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The professor is very knowledgeable of the topic and field in general. She always made sure to draw from diverse sources and over a wide range of viewpoints.

The main improvement necessary is that more scholarship of the interdisciplinary/biographical/religious nature should be written about composers other than the household names (John Cage and Steve Reich) so that this class can improve its scope. It was wonderful to learn about Meredith Monk, Ruth Crawford Seeger, etc., and I hope the opportunities to discuss such composers in music departments only increase in the future. I realize that this is not a complaint about the course per se.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I highly recommend the course to other students who are interested in musical narratives that are not saturated with musical analysis but rather steeped in forms of spiritual practices.
Kerry is a phenomenal scholar in multiple respects. Taking this course was a way to acess the rigorous, quilt-like assemblage of her critical process.
